comments.commentBody: If GOP refused to raise ceiling till 2013 Obama will announce default.I am wondering why?Few years ago debt was raised once a year.Now I guess most important for the President to be reelected.Forget about US.

The American voters put the GOP in charge of the House of Representatives in 2010. Don't blame anyone else but ourselves for this stalemate. The GOP said they would fix things but all we have seen is their insistence to bring back "Trickle Down" economic policy. Nothing more, nothing less. Let's hope that American voters will not forget the shambles that the GOP have made of running this country and fixing the economy. American voters must say No to the Party of No in 2012!
Why do these people get paid? The next biggest waste of government spending, after the wars, is their salaries and perks. And there is no end in sight! Please voters, get rid of these freeloaders!
This is the government we lecture nations all over the world to emulate?

Remember this people - remember this when campaign time and voting time come.  Don't do the usual "forget it after 10 minutes, after the pain stops", as we all seem to do.  The Dems owned Congress for 2 years, and couldn't get out of their own way.  Now the "other guys" have it easy - just say NO.  And we elected these clowns.

Government by hysteria doesn't agree with me, because no one wins and many lose.

We must do better or our future is in doubt.

No surprise that the republicans are so angry that a progressive black man is in the white house they will destroy this country just to ruin him. And so what if the rest of us get hurt, as long as the gilded 2% are fine.
If, by intransigence, our leaders fail to reach a deal and pass legislation by Aug 2, do you suppose that they will have the decency to offer their salaries as the first bill that is not paid?

Taxes need to go up, plain and simple.  The costs of not doing so will be far greater.  Krugman has it right.  The Tea Party has it wrong.  In any case, if we default, China will then have a lien on Washington, DC.  I'm sure they will do some "House"-cleaning.
Apply the 14th amendment solution. Congress has proven itself incaplable of putting country ahead of politics. We owe these debts due to decades of deficit riden budgets.
The representatives have made so many promises and commitments, to their political base, that they cannot react to the needs of the country in a crisis.

Unbelievable! No concept of what it means to lead! Republicans expect to get what they want, yet give nothing in the way of taxes, or what the democrats want.

They refuse to acknowledge that it is a two-party system; can they not understand that they must give in and meet the democrats halfway?

What is wrong with these people?

I understand the Republican politicians and their motivations to support corporations and the rich. But what I can't understand is the level of support they get from folks making less than $100K. Don't these people realize they will be hurt much more from the republican policies.

RE: “I was certain the current pickle we're in was coming when Obama extended the Bush tax cuts for the rich back in December.” msg #15

What an ignorant comment! Stick your vehemance where it belongs. It’s the electorate in 2010 that cut Obama off at the knees by voting the GOP to control congress on a blatant promise to make him fail. The GOP has been on message ever since.

Boehner represents neo-cons, libertarians, the religious right and tea party blatherers. Their fiscal plan is simple and well defined. Destroy the world economy to prevent Obama from being re-elected in 2012.

When businesses were about to go under Republicans asked for and got a $700 Billion dollar loan from the people of the United States to keep them all afloat. Now it's the people of the United States itself that needs a loan to stay afloat, and the Republicans just keep saying no, no, no. Just doesn't seem right.

It's show down at the ok corral and the game is up for the spenders. It is now and never; let the spending cuts happen.  We can't keep the debt rolling over and over as our nation sinks into bankrupt decay.

Reading the comments is encouraging. A majority of readers seem to agree that it is simply ludicrous that a right wing faction could hold an entire economy hostage in hopes of unwinding 40 years of social reform. And that our allegedly progressive president has caved early and often, and again and again allowed the Tea Party philistines to frame the debate.

What worries me is that the people who need a refresher on the economics of Herbert Hoover (and the 1937 debt freakout that prolonged the Depression) don't read the New York Times. We've all retreated into our echo chambers.

The "principles" for which the Tea Party stands are among the most ignorant I've ever seen.  But, having said that, I find it hard to believe that even the most naive of the freshman House class doesn't believe the markets will selloff, at least in the short-term, because of the indecision.  That, in turn leads me to wonder how many of their cronies aren't short the market at this very point.  The S&P is down 13 handles now as I type this.  And if you think that's bad (and it's really not, yet...), just wait until President Obama vetos this garbage they may send him.
If these people tank my savings and investment again I don't know how I can recover.  Something has got to give.

Politicians are just doing what voters demand of them: don't give an inch to the opposing party.

Politics isn't a sport where its my team v. your team. It's in the best interest of everyone if voters demand both parties sit down and have a give and take session.

The one and only thing politicians care about is getting reelected. If voters tell them to ---- or get off the pot .. or else, they'll get things done.

Well, it seems as if May 21, 2011 didn't quite do the trick, I guess it's on to plan B. I ask this naively,is this hostage negotiating where the real goal is to kill to hostage? Is this playing chicken where crashing both cars is the object? Really, what better way to undo FDR's heresy than crashing the economy? Well and nobly done, guys. Perhaps we can toast some marshmallows at the apocalypse. Should be a gas.

Couldn't we have saved a lot of time and energy if the Republicans said up front that negotiations are pointless since they are unwilling to concede anything? Because it takes an adult to recognize toddler behavior and thinking, I can forgive them.

And would someone please do an investigative article on cutting government programs? My theory is this action would actually lead to higher unemployment and a future drop in tax income that may make this option not as surefire a solution as we are being sold.

My bigger theory matches common sense - there is probably no silver bullet to fix this problem overnight. The solution likely requires that everyone make concessions and take ownership of the problem. And it must be strong enough to survive political life cycles.

It's pretty clear who really was responsible for producing the worst recession since the Great Depression and the failed, limp recovery with unemployment moving again past 9% with no end in sight.  The same people who appear to be the keystone cops of politics--the folks in Washington, DC, who can't seem to get their act together and who are bringing America to the brink of financial disaster.  Maybe it's time to turn to the IMF (perhaps DSK could put a good word in for us with some of his friends there), the World Bank, the EU, Saudi Prince Al-Waleed, George Soros and Carlos Slim, and the Peoples Republic of China.

Interesting comments.  As an ER doc death is usually immediate, and often we are now in the practice of bringing the family to the bedside if they wish to witness resuscitation.  This, although terrifying at first as an MD, often underlies what truly occurs when we fight death on behalf of the critically ill.  On the flip side, I have seen people with soon-to-be fatal conditions answer my question, 'you know you will die if I don't put this tube in, is that what you want?' with great dignity.  In that case, the family was also present, and the directness with which he said yes, and the directness of my question, with his daughters next to me, brought more dignity to his death than any euphamism ever would.  Death is brutish, smelly, and nasty; the road to dignity lies in witnessing this and rising above it with compassion and empathy.  I've never said 'passed'.  If I've not had to say 'he died' it was because they knew it when I walked in the door to the family room.
